awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to design and demonstrate integrated circuits that can generate signals at terahertz frequencies and process information at tens of giga-samples per second with low power consumption in standard silicon processes.  The approach is based on special wave propagation phenomena and applying them to nonlinear or inhomogeneous electrical lattices.

Intellectual merit: The research is focused on developing a new method of circuit design when the devices operate close to or even beyond their maximum unity power gain frequency. The main contribution is to demonstrate fundamentally novel high frequency signal generation and processing systems with orders of magnitude better performance in terms of maximum output power, operating frequency, power efficiency, and bandwidth compared to the existing methods.  

Broader impacts: The expected research results have the potential to have a transformative impact on electronic systems, such as communication devices, radars, signal sources, and processors, where higher operation frequency translates to higher data rate or better resolution. The research blends multiple disciplines within the fields of electrical engineering, applied physics and mathematics into a coherent research theme. This provides an excellent educational opportunity for the students that carry out the research. Women and minority students from underrepresented groups will be actively recruited and trained in this research environment. The research results will be used to develop new courses that emphasize on fundamental understanding and are project-based. To involve the public in the research, workshops and short online videos are planned.

por.por_cntn:
Terahertz (0.1THz - 10THz)imaging and sensing systems have many applications in bio-medical engineering, quality control, and the detection of explosives. While we are aware of advantages of imaging at this part of spectrum, the main issue is that the generation, amplification and processing of electromagnetic waves at this frequency range is very expensive and bulky. This means the general public and consumers cannot enjoy the main advantages of imaging at THz range.

In this project, we came up with a novel method to use the standard CMOS technology to realize THz systms on a single chip. CMOS process is the backbone of the electronics industry and is at the heart of cellular communications and computers among many other everyday systems. While CMOS is very low cost and readily available, it cannot operate at such high frequencies and hence most THz products use more expensive devices and processes which is not desirable.

To successfully extend the frequency range of CMOS beyond its classical capability, we combined the circuit design ideas with the physics of device and material. This means we proposed a coherent and unified design approach. Furthermore, we were inspired by the general theory of wave propagation in nature to be able to manipulate the THz waves. Examples of these wave propagation ideas can be seen in the propagation of water waves in shallow waters, the formation of clouds in sky and the propagation of light. These ideas inspired us to come up with novel circuit topologies that lead to the successful realization of THz systems in CMOS.

The complete CMOS-based THz imaging system was demonstrated in our lab (Fig.1). Using this setup, we successfully imaged various objects and two examples are shown in Fig. 2 and 3.

This project was achieved by the collaboration of 5 PhD students, 6 Masters students, 4 undergrduate researchers and 3 high school students. They learnt various aspects of the technical work as wel as other skills such as wrtiting technical papers and reports, giving public talks at the conferences and meetings. They also learnt about systematic research and how to plan solving a complicated problem at many small and calculated steps.
